newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: Malaysia end-March palm oil stock seen at 600,000T.
newsitem.headline: Malaysia end-March palm oil stock seen at 600,000T.

text.p: Malaysia's palm oil stocks are expected to drop to 600,000 tonnes at end-March 1997 from 794,000 at end-December and 699,000 tonnes at end-March in 1996, according to a report from the U.S. embassy in Kuala Lumpur.
Malaysia's Palm Oil Registration and Licensing Authority (PORLA) put end-January stocks at 696,000 tonnes, and palm oil traders had estimated end-February stocks at 595,000 tonnes.

"With a revised lower domestic crude palm oil (CPO) output anticipated for the January-March period, the palm oil stock level is expected to drop to around 600,000 tonnes at the end of March 1997," the embassy said.
Prices are expected to remain strong with stocks slipping to lower levels over the next couple of months.

Due to a double celebration of the Lunar New Year and Moslem Eid al-Fitr festival and February being a short month, the industry is expecting CPO production to drop sharply - probably in the 17-20 percent range - in February before making a strong upturn in March.
The report forecast CPO output in January-March at about 1.68 million tonnes, against 1.64 million tonnes in the same period last year.

Palm oil exports (excluding shipments of fatty acid oil distillate and all intra-Malaysia trade) were projected at 1.56 million tonnes in January-March 1997 versus 1.52 million in the same period of 1996.
